title: What Matthew uses?
description: Anticipating any questions, I’ve decided to create separate page with the specifics of software and hardware I use.
metaAlt: Centered text Stuff I use on white background

list.name: Toggl Track
list.description: to track the time of my productive activities.

list.name: Google Keep
list.description: I use it for raw notes, grocery lists and, “sudden idea” situations.

list.name: Evernote
list.description: was my primary note-taking tool for a long time (I have some notes there, but I’m switching to Notion).

list.name: Notion
list.description: an all-in-one, productive, and project management tool (todo list, notes, kanban boards, and more).

list.name: GitHub
list.description: all source code of my site is there. I also use GitHub actions for CI/CD.

list.name: Netlify
list.description: my hosting CDN. It also has additional features like anonymous analytics.

list.name: ConvertKit
list.description: when you receive an email from my Newsletter, it’s due to ConvertKit.

list.name: Udemy
list.description: a platform with educational courses. I finished some tech and creative tutorials there.

list.name: React
list.description: the most popular front-end framework. I was hesitant about JSX at first, but now I like it.

list.name: Style components
list.description: it helps me create reusable components and design primitives. My design system is consistent because of that.

list.name: Gatsby
list.description: the page you’re looking at was generated by Static Site Generator - Gatsby. It provides performance, scalability, and security out of the box.

list.name: Prettier
list.description: formats code for me. I can pay less attention to style and yet have perfect formatting.

list.name: ESLint
list.description: lints code for me. It points out when I’m doing something stupid in the code.

list.name: Jest
list.description: framework for unit testing.

list.name: Testing library
list.description: utilities that encourage good testing practices (like finding elements via ARIA roles).

list.name: Cypress
list.description: a framework for end-to-end testing. You can simulate user behavior with it (clicking, scrolling, etc.).

list.name: Cypress Axe
list.description: a library for end-to-end accessibility testing. Accessibility is a missed out aspect of many websites.

list.name: MDX
list.description: an enhanced Markdown. The main format for my content. I use it over Markdown because I can use my custom components with it.

list.name: Gatsby theme i18n & react i18next
list.description: plugins used for website internationalization.

list.name: Visual Studio Code
list.description: probably the best code editor for JavaScript. It has git integration, is easily extensible with extensions, and has many IDE-like features.

list.name: Figma
list.description: my primary design tool. It is intuitive and component-centric. Creating design systems with it is convenient. It has a growing community that produces many helpful extensions and design files. You can even access it via browser.

list.name: Notion
list.description: there is a Windows and Android app for Notion.

list.name: Google Chrome
list.description: my primary browser. It is often leading when it comes to adopting new web dev features. I use it for browsing and developing the web. Extensions:

details.name: React Dev Tools
details.description: for debugging and testing react components.

list.name: Mozilla Firefox
list.description: a supporting browser. I use it for browsing and testing feature support (I also like grid tools).

list.name: Spotify
list.description: is my audio center. I listen to the music while coding and to podcasts while walking.

list.name: Peek
list.description: handy when I want to make a gif or short screen recording on Ubuntu.

list.name: Nvidia GeForce Experience
list.description: software for updating GPU drivers, optimizing game settings, and screen recording (Windows 10).

list.name: MSI Afterburner
list.description: software for manually overclocking GPU.

list.name: Razer Synapse
list.description: an app for configuring my mouse and other Razer stuff.

list.name: Origin
list.description: I use it mainly for the Battlefield series and some EA titles.

list.name: Ubisoft Connect
list.description: I like some Ubisoft series (Assassin’s Creed, Splinter Cell, Watch Dogs).

list.name: Steam
list.description: I have other games on Steam.

list.name: Discord
list.description: for communication.

list.name: Desktop PC
list.description: my main computer. Details:

list.name: LG 27" 4k HDR (27UK650-W)
list.description: my primary monitor. It has 99% sRGB color coverage, so it produces accurate pictures. With 4k resolution, I can pack a lot of stuff on it, like 3 - 4 code files side by side. Games or movies that use HDR look very vibrant and contrasty.

list.name: LG 29" 2560x1080 (29UB65-P)
list.description: my second monitor. In portrait, writing code or browsing the web is efficient. The 21:9 ratio is convenient for one monitor but takes space next to another. I may replace it.

list.name: Razer Viper Ultimate
list.description: a wireless, lightweight mouse. Good for fps games and other things. Additionally, I may buy something more “productive” like a Logitech MX Master.

list.name: BenQ Zowie G-Sr
list.description: a mousepad for optical mouses.

list.name: Cooler Master MasterKeys Pro M (Cherry MX Brown)
list.description: my mechanical keyboard. I have had it for several years. Typing is still satisfying. I can play snake on it with LEDs. Unnecessary? Yes, but pretty cool.

list.name: HyperX Cloud II
list.description: I bought it recently, replacing the previous version. Gaming headset with an accurate audio profile that works for consuming other media. Very comfortable.

list.name: Ikea Bekant
list.description: is my corner desk. It has a big surface to work on and a clever solution for cable management - no single cable lays on the ground.

list.name: Ikea JÄRVFJÄLLET
list.description: my office chair. I like the aesthetic of it - clean and minimalistic. Not as comfortable as ergonomic chairs, but it offers decent quality for the money.

list.name: A rubber duck
list.description: helps me with hard debugging problems.

list.name: Samsung Galaxy S20FE
list.description: my primary phone. Almost a flagship, but for two-thirds the price. It has a 120Hz display with good PPI, Snapdragon 865, quality cameras, and other features like induction charging. I think in 2022, it is still a good deal.

list.name: Plantronics BackBeat Fit Sport
list.description: my Bluetooth headphones when I’m on the go. I use them when walking, running, or skipping rope.

list.name: Amazon Kindle Paperwhite 4
list.description: I like physical books. I prefer them over ebooks. Still, this portable device is perfect when I want to read something and don’t want to carry much weight.

list.name: PlayStation 4 Pro
list.description: my current console. I’ve played on Sony machines since PSX. That won’t change because I’ll probably buy PlayStation 5. I enjoy their exclusive titles, especially from Naughty Dogs. Console couch co-op is still my favorite type of multiplayer.

list.name: A Moka Pot
list.description: is an excellent alternative for a Coffeemaker. I like the whole ritual of grinding coffee beans, filling the Moka, and then waiting. Coffee just tastes better then.

list.name: A safety razor
list.description: I shave like my grandfather. I was surprised at how clean shaved my face can be using it. But it requires patience and caution. Another plus is lowering plastic usage.
